posts._title: Aleksandr Sokurov – Krug vtoroy AKA The Second Circle (1990)
posts.title: Krug vtoroy
posts.excerpt: Quote: A solitary figure trudges through the inclement weather of a vast, remote Siberian wilderness. An unyielding gust of wind brings the young man (Pyotr Aleksandrov) to his knees as he attempts to avert the caustic, sustained force of the snowstorm, momentarily obscuring him from view, erased from the harsh and desolate landscape. The stark, …

posts.title: Predstavleniye
posts.excerpt: Sergei Loznitsa has once again scoured the Russian film archives for REVUE, selecting excerpts from newsreels, propaganda films, TV shows and feature films that present an evocative portrait of Soviet life during the 1950s and 1960s. With scenes taken from the length and breadth of the Soviet Motherland, REVUE illustrates industry and agriculture (dam construction, …

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Picknick mit Weismann aka Picnic With Weissmann (1968)
posts.title: Picknick mit Weismann
posts.excerpt: Various objects are having a sunny outing together in the nature.

posts.title: Et Cetera
posts.excerpt: A small, animated figure learns how to use a whip, a pair of wings and a house.

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Rakvickarna AKA Punch and Joey AKA The Coffin Factory (1968)
posts.title: Rakvickarna
posts.excerpt: Two puppets, Punch and Joey, do battle to the death over the custody of a live guinea pig.

posts.title: Hra s kameny
posts.excerpt: Stones of different shapes and colors live and die together.

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Johann Sebastian Bach: Fantasia G-moll (1965)
posts.title: Johann Sebastian Bach: Fantasia G-moll
posts.excerpt: A man plays the Bach piece of the title on the organ, accompanied by images of stone walls with cracks and holes that grow and shrink, intercut with images of doors and wire-meshed windows.

posts.title: Lolita
posts.excerpt: Quote: “How did they make a movie out of Lolita?” teased the print ads of this Stanley Kubrick production. The answer: by adding three years to the title character’s age. The original Vladimir Nabokov novel caused no end of scandal by detailing the romance between a middle-aged intellectual and a 12-year-old nymphet. The affair is …
